communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Service Maritime Roumain

Par suite de la quarantaine de 48 houres imposée par la Turquie aux provenances d'Egypte les paquebots-poste du Service Maritime Roumain quitteront Alexandrie chaque quinzaine le Mercredi à 4 heures de l'après midi. Au cas où cette quarantaine serait réduite à 24 heures seulement les départs auront lieu le Jeudi à 4 p.m.
Alexandrie, le 25 Juin 1907.

div.head: MISS CORELLI ON MAN.
div.p: "To put it bluntly and plainly," writes Miss Marie Corelli in the "Introductory Note" to her new book, "Delicia" (Constable), "a great majority of the men of the present day want women to keep them. It is these very men," she adds, "who at their clubs, or any other places where they can give themselves sublime airs of independence, frequently express regret in grandiloquent terms that there should be any women who want to be clever.' Such women | are always 'unsexed."

"This word 'unsexed,' ' Miss Corelli continnes, "is always cast at brilliant women by every little halfpenny ragamuffin of the Press that can get a newspaper corner in which to hide himself for the convenience of throwing stones. The woman who paints a great picture is 'unsexed'; the woman who writes a great book is 'unsexed'; in faet, whatever woman does that is higher and more ambitious than the mere act of flinging herself down at the feet of man and allowing him to walk over her, makes her in man's opinion unworthy of his consideration as woman."

"What," Miss Corelli asks, "are the occupations man graciously permits to woman without affronting her by this opprobious epithet. He is chiefly willing to see her on the stage. And he generally prefers the music hall stage as the best one fitted to her poor' abilities. It is no particular 'fun' to him to see her rise to the histrionic height of a Rachelor a Sarah Bernhardt. Nor does the exquisite grace of the finished 'comedienne' delight him entirely. No ! Neither the height of tragedy nor comedy in the woman on the stage really satisfy men so | much as the happy medium-the particular 'no-man's-land' of art, where nothing is demanded of her but-body and grin. A beantiful | body, trained to walk and look well--an affable grin, expanding at the sight of champagne and other mundane delicacies--these are all that is necessary.

"Now, if this beautiful body be well-nigh stripped to man's gaze night after night on the boards, he will never call the woman who so exposes herself 'unsexed, nor will he apply the word to her if she drinks too much wine and brandy. But if another woman, with quite AS beautiful a body, instead of exhibiting | herself half nude on the music hall stage, prefers to keep her woman's modesty, and execute some great work of art which shall be | as good and even better than anything man can accomplish, she will be dubbed 'unsexed instantly.
"I ask-Why is it that man elects to compass woman's degradation rather than hec uplifting and sanctification ?"

Miss Corelli alludes to "a certain individual, looked upon with a considerable amount of respect by the titled and monied classes, who married a bright little woman for her money, and since then has made her life an hourly misery." Miss Corelli also speaks of the miserable position voluntarily held by certain 'noblemen' who, because they have placed themselves in the unnatural and unbecoming condition of owing everything to their wives' money, permit those wives to play fast and | loose with their honour and good name, and apparently shut their eyes to the shameless infidelities which make them the by-word and contempt of all self-respecting 'commoners.'

"It would be a wholesome and refreshing stimulus to society," she adds, "if such 'blueblooded lacqueys could awake to the fact that manbood is better than money, and would by their own free will and choice go out to hard | labour in the goldfields or elsewhere and earn their own livelihood bravely and independently, instead of lounging and frittering their days away, the silent and inactive spectators of | their wives' open and wanton degradation."

div.p: The Alexandria Court of Assizes has condemned to death Aly El Senoussi convicted of murdering his sister on the 8th of April last. The girl, it will be remembered, was shot by Senoussii for having married against his will.

div.p: The Municipality of Alexandria has allotted a sum of £1,500 for the transfer of the statue of the late Mohamed Aly Pasha from its present position in the centre of the square to lis the new northern square close to the new quay.

div.head: Sentences for Theft.
div.p: Aly Hassan Kabab has been sentenced to three months' hard labour for having stolen P.T. 522 from a passenger at Cairo station. Aly Abdel Nebi has been condemned to a similar sentence for forging a Customs certificate.

div.head: The Sacred Carpet.
div.p: The designs on which the sacred carpet is to be modelled have been submitted to the an Ministry of Finance which has given its approval. The making of the carpet will necessitate the employment of 500 okes of silk, of which 200 for the chain will be of the quality called aksira and 300 of Italian silk for the me weft.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Birth Rate.
div.p: The report of the Alexandria Municipality shows that during last year there was a remarkable falling off in the number of births belonging to members of the Church of England at Alexandria. The average number of births registered at the Anglican Church in Alexandria during the three years 1903-4-5 was 24 per annum. Last year, however, the total fell to 14. The members of the Scotch Church here improved on their average, which during these three years was 9 births per annum. Last year the Scotch births amounted to 12.

div.head: Collapse of a House.
div.p: About five o'clock yesterday morning a house in the thickly populated quarter of Manasra at Cairo consisting of three storeys, and occupied by working people and their families, collapsed, and buried under its ruins many of the sleeping inhabitants. Rescue was speedily to hand and excellent work was done by the police and by the fire brigade, and it was not long before most of the bodies were recovered, though regrettably two deaths are recorded, while three persons have been more or less severely injured. At four o'clock yesterday afternoon the last body was recovered, life being extinct.

There was a meeting yesterday at Manchester to consider the policy that should be followed at the present juncture. The practical results of the meeting were unsatisfactory, as it is found to be a difficult business to bring the various parties interested into line.

div.head: GOLD IN SINAI.
div.p: In Egypt proper between the 22nd and 28th parallels of north latitude gold is now known to be widely distributed in both the older sedimentary and plutonic rocks, and more especially in the neighbourhood of, or actually in the less acid granites (hornblende granites), quartzdiorites, and diorites which often appear to form well-defined zones, near the junction of the granites with the ancient sedimentaries. As rocks of the last named type are largely developed in Eastern Sinai, the report on that part of Egypt, which has just been issued by the Survey Department, contains an interesting account of their distribution, and may prove of material aid to the prospector.

In many cases despite the large number of ancient workings, it has been most difficult to obtain even traces of gold at the surface, but deeper excavations have led to the finding of rich one bodies in some of the Egyptian mines. The want of superficial deposits is largely accounted for by the removal of the outcrops and weathered portions of auriferous bodies by the ancients, and in any case patient search and study of the various formations has been necessary to locate the old shutes ; such work does not come within the functions of a rapid geological survey, whose object must be to lay a wide general foundation on which more detailed research may be based.
Summarizing with regard to the occurrence of gold in Sinai it may be stated :--
1. That the similarity of the formations to those of the Eastern Deserts of Egypt is a hopeful indication that auriferous deposits will occur.
2. Only a systematic search by prospectors can prove the existence or non-existence of gold.
3. The quartz region near the foot of Gebel Abu Mesud may be indicated as one of the most likely spots at which to commence such an exploration.
From time to time expeditions have been made by various exploring parties into the Sinai Peninsula, but unfortunately but little of their data has been published.

div.head: MR. MONTAGUE SUMMERS ON EGYPTIAN STABILITY.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, I notice a paragraph in your issue of yesterday's date under the above heading in which the astounding statement is made that 120,000 tourists had visited Egypt last winter season, and had spent in his (Mr. Summers) estimation 18 millions sterling !! Taking all the hotels in Egypt, including Alexandria, Port Said, Cairo, Luxor, and Assouan, that cater for the tourist trade, a total of five thousand beds would be a very liberal estimate, and taking that each one of these beds was occupied for 100 nights during the season, also a liberal estimate, we would have a total of 500,000 beds occupied for one night each, or if you' give each tourist an average stay of 25 days we would have a total number of 20,000 tourists ; half that number instead of 120,000 is probably the correct figure. Again if you allow for each tourist and expenditure of two "pounds per day, the above calculation would amount to one million sterling instead of eighteen millions. I once heard a native proverb which roughly translated says "a hungry man dreams of loaves of bread". Mr. Montague Summers, if correctly reported, must have surely been indulging in a summer's daydream.
Yours faithfully
div.note: [We believe that the total number of first class passengers, which almost entirely include the tourist class, who landed in Egypt last season, did not exceed 12,000. Ed. E.G.)

div.head: OKAPI IN THE SUDAN
div.p: A note in the "Bulletin," of the Paris Museum, indicates that Captain (now Colonel) Marchand, of Fashoda fame, was the first European to see that interesting African ani. mal, the Okapi, alive. Some extracts are given from the journal kept by Captain Marchand on his expedition from the Congo to Fashoda. From these it appears that on the southern watershed of the Bahr-el-Ghazal, Marchand saw in a herd of antelopes a creature such as he had never seen before. It had a giraffe-like Deck and horns, the body was reddish brown in colour, while the limbs and hind-quarters were striped. This was in 1898. From the description, Professor Menegaux, who writes the note, is convinced that the unknown creature was the Okapi, which was thus seen for the first time in the flesh by a European.

div.head:
THE NILE.
PROSPECTS OF THE FLOOD.
div.p: During the last two or three days a rise of about one metre has taken place in the level of the Atbara River. This rise has been sustained and may possibly improve the levels generally. The flood, however, up to now considered as a whole seems so far as can be judged up to the present date, to be some a what late in its coming. What has arrived is below the average. This slight lateness of the flood will not affect the cotton crop or the watering of the sharaki lands, as the irrigation of these cultivations are proceeding in a satisfactory manner from the good supplies of water sent down by the Assouan Reservoir.

The critical period may be said to be the first 10 days of August, as the volume of the flood depends on the level attained by the Blue Nile at say, Roseires, being maintained for sufficient time in August. In 1903 the river on August 12 rose to & gauge reading of 20-8 metres and then fell slowly throughout the month. In 1904 it rose to 20-5 metres on July 31, then tell abruptly, 18-5 metres being mean for August in that year. On the ground of this and other information the prediction was made last year at the beginning of August that the Hood would be near the average, and that no grounds existed for expecting that it would exceed it to any extent. In the case of last year's flood, the general character of this period of six weeks 1 July 15 August was that the supply, which was below the average at first, improved rapidly towards the end.

Last year the Atbara at Khashm el Girba rose markedly at the end of July and the early part of August, so that at Wadi Halfa the level reached the mean of the 15 years 1890-1904 in August, but did not exceed it until the end of the month.

div.head: DAMASCUS-BEYROUT LINE.
div.p: The Turkish Government during next month will dispose of a collection of Government stamps numbering 17,000,000. The collection contains specimens of current stamps of the realm, and also specimens which are valuable from a collector's point of view. There are also & number of Eastern Roumelian stamps. The sale will be effected by tender. Each Turkish Embassy and Legation is supplied with albums containing specimens of the stamps, and also copies of the conditions of sale, the latter being in the course of translation from Turkish. The proceeds of the sale are to form a nucleus for the building fund of the new railway to be constructed between Damascus and Beyrout. It is understood that a number of stamp connoisseurs have already inspected the collection. Particulars may be obtained at the Turkish Embassy.

div.head: A SYRIAN DRAGOMAN.
div.p: Said Kalil Haick, a young Syrian dragoman, just arrived in New York has announced that he was engaged to marry Miss Elsie Ellwood, danghter of Mr. W. L Ellwood and granddaughter of Colonel Isaac L. Ellwood, of| Dekalb, Ill. Colonel Ellwood, as a partner of Mr. John W. Gates, made many millions of dollars in the steel and wire business. Suid Haick is interested with Mr. Homer Davenport in the importation of Arabian horses at Dekalb. Mr. E. Perry Ellwood, son of Colonel Ellwood, said no Miss Elsie Ellwood he knew was engaged, and that he knew nothing of any contemplated marriage of any granddaughter of Colonel Isaac Ellwood.

Said Haick said; "I became acquainted with Miss Ellwood while acting as dragoman of her party in the desert and came to New York on the same ship with her and her mother." When asked when the ceremony would be performed, the Syrian grew vague.

div.head:
MUNICIPALITY REPORT.
PUBLIC HEALTH OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: One of the most interesting chapters, and probably the most instructive to the general public, of the Municipality report for 1906 is. that of Dr. Gotsoblich dealing with the sanitary service of the Municipality. Every section with which Dr. Gotschlich deals is full of interest and, therefore, we will not attempt to deal with his report in one issue, to do which would require too much generalisation to do justice to so important a branch of the Municipal Administration.

THE POPULATION.-Dr. Gotschlich first gives a few details of the population of Alexandria, which, he estimates, was on July, 1, 1906, 400,159, of which 332,586 were native inhabitants, and 67,566 foreigners.

He points out, however, that these figures cannot be vouched for as accurate, they being based upon the census of 1897 and the calculation of the increase in population being proportional to the increase of birth rate, but the great difficulty in ascertaining with accuracy the number of births must be remembered, there being no law compelling Europeans to register. It can be taken for granted, however, that the figure given is the minimum. Though in all probability the birth rate has a tendency to decrease, there is every indication that immigration has greatly increased. Upon sach bases Dr. Gotschlich Estimates that the death rate, instead of being 29.2%, as by the figures adopted, is probably 28.7%.

BIRTHS. During 1906, 13,937 native births were registered, as compared with the average of 12,743 for the years 1901 to 1905. Of these 13,641 were Mohamedans and 896 natives of other religions. According to the register of baptisms, however, the births of non-Mohamedans totalled 1,083, so that at least 17% were not made known to the sanitary authorities. Of births of foreigners only 668 were declared, while the baptism registries give a total of 1,571.

DEATHS. The deaths during 1906 totalled 11,683, of which 10,755 were natives, and the average death rate for the last decade is given as 31.2 %, while the average from 1901 to 1906 is 29:6 %. The highest figure during this latter period is registered for 1902 when the cholera epidemic largely accounted for a death rate of 34.3 %. In 1906 the actual number of deaths among adults was normal and it has been almost constant since 1901 ; and seeing that it is the adult population and not the infant population, owing to immigration, which is increasing, the death rate among adults is decreasing and therefore it may be assumed that the sanitary | conditions are improving. The death rate among native infants is almost 66 % and among foreign infants it is only 83% The number of deaths before the age of one year WAS 4,006 native and 193 European, with respective averages during the last five years of 3,630 and 183. From one to five years old the figures are 2,667 (average 2,552) natives, and 105 (average 127) Europeans.

INFECTIOUS DISEASES. — During 1906 there were in all 97 cases of plague recorded, 62 of which (64%) terminated fatally, but of these 62 only 7 were Europeans, among whom 18 cases were declared. 186 cases of diphtheria were notified and of these 94 (51%) died : practically 50% of the cases were natives, but among them the mortality was far heavier in in proportion, 63 out of 92 being fatal cases. of the 132 typhoid fever cases notified 64 | were Europeans, 59 Egyptians, and 9 Ottoman subjects, the deaths being respectively 31, 51, and 7. The death rate from typhoid, therefore, among Europeans was about 50% | while among the natives it was almost 100%. 92 cases of small-pox were notified, of which 36 terminated fatally. There were 631 deaths from tuberculosis among the natives and 83 Europeans died from this disease.
On the subject of infectious diseases Dr. Gotschlich says:

It is satisfactory to note that the frequency of infectious diseases has diminished during 1906 very remarkably, if one compares the figures of deaths for that year with those of 19 3 to 19' 5. Diphtheria alone shows a slight increase, though without reaching the level of 1905, while all the others show a considerable decrease."
For 1907, however, we shall most certainly see higher figures both as regards the plague and small-pox.

The figures for hydrophobia are very interesting and it is notable that last year no death from this fatal disease was recorded. In 1905 there were 19 mad animals, 28 people bitten, and 2 deaths; in 1903 there were 16 mad animals, 36 people bitten, and 4 deaths; and 111906 there were 4 mad animals, 4 persons bitten, and no deaths.

div.head: ACROSS THE SAHARA.
div.p: The Paris newspapers report that Captain Arnaud, of the Colonial Infantry, has succeeded in marching from Algiers to Kotonu, on the coast of Dahomey, due south of Algeria, in 127 days.
He covered a distance of 8120 miles, including over 700 miles over a new ronte. The expedition met with no opposition.-Reuter.
With this may be compared the 1700 miles joumey last autumn from Tripoli across the
Eastern Sahara to Lake Chad of Mr. Vischer,
the British resident at Kuka, on Lake Chad.

His progress was much slower, as he took about 460 days over the 1700 miles, as against the Frenchman's 127 days for 3120 miles ; but it must be remembered that Mr. Vischer was a civilian, and travelled with an ordinary caravan, which was attacked by Maregs.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA.
THE MAKING OF BYE-LAWS.
div.byline: BY R. WILLIAMS F.R I B.A.
div.p: In the making of laws or bye-laws, any regulation which primarily should tend to har monize the varied amenities of life, the greatest care is needed, lest by any chance, legislators, national or local, should by their law or regulation making, play into the hands of selfishness and greed. In all laws and bye-laws there must be room for the foll play of honest discretion and, above all, of equity.

As an illustration of what is meant above, let us take the question of the foundation of a wall which abuts a neighbour's land. That is to say, a proprietor desires to build upon his boundary. Now, it is a well known fact (not a mere theory of the axiom) that unless a wall has a foundation, considerably broader than the breadth or thickness of the superincumbent wall, it will be unsafe. But in order that the proprietor should be able to realise, without detriment to his neighbour, the full benefit of his land he must be allowed to build the projecting part of his foundation (below the surface of the ground) upon his neighbour's land. This can be done without harm to the neighbour, but the refusal to allow this accomodation can be, as pointed out already, harmful to the proprietor who wants build.

Under the London Building Act, all that is required is a notice to the adjoining owner that that proprietor is going to build and will put footings on the adjoining owner's land. This is only reasonable. But strange as it may seem here in Egypt, where long before the days of Herodotus (who noticed the aberration) it is still the custom to do things inversely. The Oairo Tanzim, SO my builder informs me, refused to allow him to put the footings of a wall he was building at Port Said on the land of the adjoining owner. This is, I am told, a Tanzim regulation. A regulation, be it understood, calculated to make of a new building a dangerous structure. Herein is another hint to the Alexandria bye-law makers.

Take another case. A case where preeminently equity should play the more prominent part. A manufacturer having established a business, which, for between forty and fifty years he has honourably conducted and to the benefit of Egypt and of Egyptians, finds himself in this late day, being overreached by a neighbour who, presuming upon his knowledge that a building roksa or permit bad not been obtained by the manufacturer, proceeded to build some cottages on land near by and to promptly object to the proximity of workshop premises ! The neglect to obtain a roksa by the manufacturer can well be understood as he was established before the days of modern roksas. But what would be the result, supposing the object neighbour should gain his point. He will be able to buy the land deserted by the workshops at a cheap rate.

The case of the footings can be dealt with effectively in a bye-law, but the latter case is one (and many similar cases may arise, for selfishness and greed often goes to inordinate | lengths) which requires the utmost wisdom, and can only be decided by the universal law which Emerson called "the law of give and take" but which was better said by another teacher in the words, "Do unto others as ye would that others should do unto you."

Building laws are the result of compromise between conflicting causes. On the one hand our experience of trade and of life generally make certain demands on space, construction and sanitary arrangement; and on the other hand there is the question of cost, value of land and return on capital outlay. These considerations are in conflict, consequently the resulting laws always fall short of the true ideal. It is permissible to say that did we but realise the highest ideals with regard to our lives, laws would not be required.

Ancient Rome had its building laws as Vitruvius tells us, yet in the days of Augustus there was a crowding of tall buildings in narrow streets and a crowding of people within the buildings, accompanied by the resulting insanitation and disease.
The London building and health laws are among the most comprehensive of all such laws, yet crowding is rampant.

In the making of building laws, Alexandria | has a special advantage. Its Municipality can profit by the failures and experience of other cities, but while we recognise this, we must not forget that Alexandria is beset with other than the usual set of difficulties. The Capitulations present no small hindrance to the proper working of a sanitary and building code. Yet we may well suppose that for the benefit of the city in which they (some of them) make their fortunes and occasionally lose them, the beneficiaries by the Capitulations will surely brush aside all difficulties on that hend, and give to the Municipality 'a free hand in the making of laws for the health and safety and shall we say, beauty, of the town.
The essentials of the necessary bye-laws may be enumerated as follows -
1. The laying out of streets and of rainage, and of sewerage.
2. Naming streets.
3. Open spaces.
4. Construction.
5. Dangerous structures.
6. Temporary structures.
7. Dangerous businesses and factories
8. Duties of superintending architect, chief engineer and building inspectors
9. Procedure as to building notices.

In my next paper I shall deal with the first three points, with especial reference to the voluminous and exhaustive report of the Royal Comission on London Traffic, a work from which the Municipality of Alexandria may gather many useful hints.
(To be continued).

We are glad to learn of the completo recovery of Mr. de Reffye.

Mr. James Currie, Dicector of Public Instruction in the Sudan will arrive Sunday that in Cairo, to recruit 10 teachers of English and Mathematics for the Sudan. 60 candidates have already applied for 8 vacant posts. The teachers will be of Egyptian nationality.

The following were among those who left for Constantinople yesterday by the Khedivial Mail S.S. "Kahira" Hussein Pasha Boucbdi, Mr. S. Varilass, Mrs. Cahorean, Mr, and Mrs.. Hassan Bey Zayed, Baroness Schilling Me Jeromides, Mrs. G. Sabet Bey, Ibrahim Boy Hacky, Osinan Bey Aly.

div.head:
THE "TIMES" AND MR BLUNT
IS HE A MINOR POET
div.p: Mr. Wilfrid Blunts recent book, on Egypt has led to a dicussion in the "Athenaeum" of: the rights and responsibilities of the historian and to certain criticisms in the Times" and "Punch" which have called down the Wrath of the "Academy." This paper, in its issue of July 6, says :-"The Times" has no more right to call Mr. Blunt a minor poet then it i has to call Byron & minor poet, less right indeed. It was the "Times" I understand which when 'In Memoriam' was anonymously published, referred to it as this touching -poem, evidently the work of the widow o n military man,' and it will be the "Times undoubtedly who, if and when a new Keata arises in the land, will tell him to go back to his gallipots. "IL," adds the writer, "the "Times" has not the sense to see that Mr. Blant is not a 'minor poet, it might at least appreciate that he is probably one of the greatest masters of English prose that has appeared in the last hundred years."

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est toujours à 3 1/2 pourcent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a encore perdu hier 1/8 à 83 5/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 101 1/2. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 à 19 1/4. L'A. gricole s'est maintenue à 8, de même que la Daïra Sanieh à 13 5/8 et la Delta Light à 9 5/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Poncier Egyptien a rétrogradé de 2 francs à 680. La Banque d'Athènes a perdu 1 franc à 108. Les Lots Turcs sont demeurés stationnaires à 166 francs.

Ici, la situation du marché devient de jour en jour plus normale et en même temps plus rassurante. Les denx gros problèmes qui pouvaient déterminer une nouvelle dépression, pour ne pas dire une débâcle, se trouvent résolus de la manière la plas satisfaisante possible. Aussi bien les esprits se sont rassérénés, la confiance renait, et les fausses rumeurs alarmantes, répandues avec une constance et une habileté dignes d'un meilleur sort par les baissiers, n'exercent plus la moindre action sur la cote. Certes, les séances ne brillent pas par une activité excessive, mais il n'en était guère autrement les années précédentes pendant la S période des vacances. On peut, tout au contraire, soutenir que l'animation est beaucoup plus grande actuellement en corbeille qu'à pareille époque en 1906, 1905 ou 1904. C'est, du reste, là un des effets mêmes de la crise que nous venons de traverser ; la baisse outrée qui l'a marquée sert déjà visiblement de base et de motif à la reprise qui se produira avant le terme ordinaire assigné à la morte saison.
En réalité, la séance de ce matin, qu'on se plaisait à prévoir mauvaise ou tout an moins, décevante, a été, au fond, relativement bonne.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National & avancé à 19 3/16-1/4 et l'Agricole à 7 13/16-7/8. La Banque d'Athènes s'est raffermie à 108.
La Daïra Sanieh s'est inserite en progrs à 13 1/2. Les obligations à lots anciennes du Credit Poncier se sont consolidées à 300 ; les nouvelles ont progressé à 257.

L'Agricole du Nil a été ramenée à 210. Les fondateurs Heliopolis ont été moins bien tenns à LE 10 5/8. Les Jouissances Eaux da Caire se sout tassées à 186-187. La Brasserie des Pyramides est remontée à 78, mais sa part a faibli à 30. Les Automobiles ont avancé à 1 15/16-2.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Egyptian se sont alourdis & 5 1/16-1/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est tassée à 1 1/4-5/16. Très malmenés à la suite de certaines rumeurs, les Estates sont tombés à 0 3/8-7/16 et leur part à 2. Rien de particulier à relever sur les autres titres.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 19 Juillet, le passage suivant :

"En général les cours de clôture des valeurs égyptiennes an Stock Exchange sont inférieurs à ceux de la semaine précédente ; mais il est indéniable que les ventes ont été aisément absorbées et que le marché montre une résistance de très bon augure pour l'avenir. L'opinion prévaut, d'ailleurs, qu'il faut s'attendre à une bonne reprise dans ce compartiment dès que les ventes forcées auront cessé.

La National Bank a reculé de 19 5/16 à 18 1/2 pour remonter à 18 27/32. L'Agricole a fléchi de 7 13/16 & 7 1/2 pour reprendre à 7 11/16. La Daïra Sanieh & rétrogradé de 13 1/2 à 13 1/4. La Delta Light a continué d'être l'objet de demandes suivies entre 9 1/2 et 9 11/16 avec un bon courant d'affaires.

" Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land, de 1 11/16 avec coupon, a faibli à 1 5/16 excoupon de 3 shellings. Les Estates ont été largement offerts, revenant de £03/4 à 011/16. Après un long laps d'inactivité, les parts de fondateur Estates ont été échangées aujourd'hui à 4 8/4-7/8. Les Markets ont été recherchés, passant de 27 à 28 sh. Par contre, les Salt and Soda ont été faibles ; des ordres de vente provenant d'Egypte les ont ramenés de 18 à 16 sh.9. Les New Egyptian sont restés dans les environs de 0 11/16. Les Aboukir ont donné lieu à un certain nombre de transactions, mais sont restés à peu près inchangés à 1 9/16 ex-coupon. Les United Lands ont été négligés & 011/32. Les Khedivial Mail ordinaires ont été activement échanges anx environs de 20 sh."

la baisse du Consolide et des autres fonds d'Etat en Angleterre et la stagnation du Stock Exchange pendant une époque marquée par une si grande activité industrielle et commerciale, tel est le sujet intéressant que M. Asquith, chancelier de l'Echiquier, à abordé récemment dans un discours prononcé à l'occasion de l'inauguration des nouveaux locaux de l'Institution générale de prévoyance et de tempérance du Ro. yaume-Uni.

"Depuis un an, a-t-il dit, on a entendu beaucoup de raisonnements faux au sujet de la prétendue dépression du crédit national. Or, tous ceux qui se sont donné la peine de procéder à une petite comparaison ont pu se rendre compte que la dépréciation subie par nos fonds nationaux a été inférieure à celle dont ont été atteintes les valenr d'autres pays. En outre, on ne se rend pas compte du facteur qui domine la situation. Certes, il s'est produit des circonstances qui ont contribué à la baisse dont le Stock Exchange nous a offert le spectacle. Mais leur influence n'a été que momentanée. En réalité la dépression de notre Bourse est due en grande partie à l'activité et à la prospérité de notre commerce. Il est évident quo lorsque les gens peuvent obtenir 5 et

6% de leurs capitaux, ils ne se contenteront pas facilement du 2, 21 ou même du 3% La dépréciation de nos meilleures valeurs provient donc de la concurence que lenr font d'autres emplois plus rémunérateurs qui s'offrent aux capitaux."

Le chancelier de l'Echiquier croit cependant que l'on & touché le fond de la baisse et qu'une réaction est certaine ; toutefois il ne peut s'aventurer à prédire le nombre de courbes que fera la ligne destinée à mar. quer cette reprise, qui est inévitable.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de l'Ibrahimieh Ploughing Co, en liquidation sont informés qu'une première répartition de l'actif, à concurrence de £ 1 par action ordinaire sera faite, à partir du ler Août prochain, au Caire an siège social, et à Paris à la Société Générale.

A en croire des informations transmises de Londres, il serait sérieusement question de porter le capital de l'Egyptian Estates Ltd. £ 1,001,000 par la création de 501,000 actions ordinaires nouvelles de £ 1 chacune.

Le conseil d'administration de la Banque d'Orient a décidé le paiement, à partir du ler Août prochain, d'un dividende de Frs. 2.50 par action sur les bénéfices réalisés du 1er semestre de l'année courante.
Ce dividende será payé, aux guichets de la Banque, contre remise du coupon No. 2.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société Anonyme des Ciments d'Egypte, tenue le 16 Juillet courant à Bruxelles, a approuvé à l'unanimité les rapports du conseil d'administration et des censeurs, ainsi que le bilan et compte de profits et pertes de l'exercice 1906.
Elle a ensuite ratifié la nomination, en qualité d'administrateur, de M. J. Joannides et pris note de la démission de MM. Stevenart, J. Festa et Dumonceau.

Le conseil d'administration de la Société se compose actuellement de cinq membres, savoir : J. G. Chakour pacha, président et administrateur-délégué; J. Debonne, admi. nistrateur technique ; MM. L. Carton de Wiart, F. Lambert et J. Joannides.

L'Assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Banque Française d'Egypte a eu lieu à Pa ris le 16 Juillet courant sous la présidence de M. le baron d'Orgeval, président du conseil d'administration de cette nouvelle Société.

L'Assemblée a adopté les modifications proposées aux articles 44 et 47 des statuts en ce qui concerne l'année sociale. Celle-ci était primitivement fixée du ler Janvier au 31 Décembre. Or, pour des raisons d'ordre in. térieur, elle est dorénavant fixée du 1er Juillet au 30 Juin et exceptionnellement pour le premier exercice, du 31 Mai 1907 au 30 Juin 1908.
L'assemblée a ensuite approuvé le traité intervenu entre le conseil d'administration et M. le comte Cressaty, directeur général de la Banque du Caire.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Bgyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public, qu'elle recevra jusqu'au Mardi, vingt Août prochain, à midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture de quarante cinq mille mètres carrés de pierre volcanique de la meilleure qualité dont le Service de la Voie aura besoin pour ses travaux pendant une année, selon échantillon à soumettre au dit Service, livrables à raison de 3750 mètres carrés par mois, suivant les conditions du Cahier des Charges relatif à cette fourniture dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire au Service Central deg Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire), et au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) contre paiement de cent millièmes.

Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication, devra verser, au préalable, à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration, à titre de cautionnement provisoire, une somme de cent livres Egyptiennes. Le soumissionnaire déclare adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence du dix pour cent du mon tant de l'offre agréée.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente millièmes ainsi que du reçu constatant le versement du cautionnement provisoire susdit. Elles seron adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé å:
Monsieur le Directeur Général
des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Caire et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portan la suscription suivante :
Soumission pour la fourniture de pierr volcanique pour le service de la Voie.
Toute offre faite ou déposée postérieuremen | au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne seri pas prise en considération.

L'Adininistration se réserve le droit de choi sir parmi les offres faites celles qui lui con viennent, sans être tenue d'accepter l'offre 1 plus basse. Elle se réserve de même le droit d diviser la commande et de ne donner aucun suite aux soumissions présentées, quels qu soient les prix soumis. • Le Caire, le 24 Juillet 1907. 30695-2

div.head:
THE KOREAN TROUBLE.
JAPANESE WARSHIPS ARRIVE.
NEW CONVENTION CONCLUDED.

div.p: Three Japanese warships with troops have arrive at Chemulpo. The troops accompanied by a strong force of bluejackets are coming here. The popular disquiet throughout Korea is heightened by a heat drought.
(Reuter)

A new convention between Japan and Korea has been concluded. It invests the ResidentGeneral with complete control of international administration and it appoints Japanese to horean government offices.
(Renter)

div.head:
IRISH COAL FAMINE.
SPINNING MILL CLOSED.
4.000 HANDS IDLE.

div.p: Come of the largest Spinning Mills, employing 4000 hands, has been closed owing to a coal famine in consequence of the strike of dockers. At a meeting of police increased pay was demanded in consequence of the extra work through the strike which is attended with considerable violence.
(Reuter)

div.head:
ZANZIBAR COAST SLAVERY.
COST OF ABOLITION.

div.p: The compensation for the abolition of slavery along the Zanzibar coast will amount to £40,000
(Reuter)

div.head:
JAPANESE IN FRANCE.
LUNCH AT THE ELYSÉE

div.p: After having been received by Mr. Thomson, the officers of the Japanese squadron, which is at Brest, lunched at the Elysée. M. Fallières regarded the visit as a prelude to closer relations. The Japanese ambassador thanked him.
(Havas)

div.head: KING EDWARD. VISIT TO KAISER ANNOUNCED.

div.p: It is semi officially stated that King Edward will visit the Emperor at Wilhelmshoehe on 14th August.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE MILITARY AIRSHIP.
FIRST TRIALS SATISFACTORY.

div.p: The first trials of the military airship have taken place. It manquvred for 3 hours with the utmost precision. It is claimed to outstrip the "Patrie".
(Reuter)
A directible military balloon has been put under trial and manceuvred with precision.
(Havas)
King Edward and Emperor William will have a private interview at Wilhelmshoche on August 14.
(Havas)
The court-martial has suspended the commander of the cruiser "Jean Bart," which stranded on 29th February last on the Aquin Reef, for 5 years.
(Reuter)
The "Gaulois" says that Generals Baillond and Gallieni will replace Generals Machal and Metzinger, resigned.
(Havas)
The King and Queen will visit Emperor Francois Joseph during August
(Havas)

div.head: EGYPTIAN PRISONS.
div.p: COLES PASHA'S REPORT.

As prisons are completed and the system of administration perfected, the establishments have to be increased. In the year under review this increase consists of 3 medical officers, 2 directors of works, 2 store-keepers, 14 clerks and 10 temporary clerks. 56 men have also been added to the warders, their ratio to prisoners being now 5.45%.
The balance sheets of the prison industries show a profit of L.E. 14,945 or L.E. 1,451 in excess of any previous year.

The Abou-Zaabal Prison must be credited with the increased profits from stone quarrying, and in the matter of industries Tantah and Zagazig Prisons shew the best results as, although the revenue from Cairo is largely in excess of either, it is due entirely to the laundry. In fact with the exception of the laundry and the saddlers' shop, the revenue from Cairo Prison industries is somewhat disappointing owing perhaps to the fact that at Cairo and Tura a larger amount of unremunerative labour is done for the Prisons Department than in other prisons. Undoubtedly better results could be obtained if certain industries in particular prisons were abolished and the output from other industries increased. This matter is receiving my attention, but the educational side of the question must not be lost sight of, neither is it desirable to flood the market with any particular class of prison made goods and thus unduly compete with free labour.

The total expenditure (other than for buildings) of the Department was £.E.117,653 or £.E. 7,178 in excess of the previous year. The excess (£.E. 8111) coming under the head of establishment, more than accounts for this increase, but apart from establishment the prices of the necessities of life in general have risen all round and the average number of prisoners being less, the cost of maintenance per prisoner works out higher than in any previous year.

With the continued rise in the cost of provisions and salaries of officers, it makes it very difficult, if not impossible, to draw upestimates based on expenditure of previous years and I judging from the contract rates for the current year we have by no means reached the limit. I lose po opportunity of instilling on my subordinates the necessity of economy, but I have no control over the expenditure of many chapters of the Prison Budget and with these figures constantly before me, I may be pardoned for endeavouring, by all the means in my power to influence magistrates and others to imprisor only those who are a danger to the community when at large.

The details of expenditure on new prison: will be found in the report of the Director of Buildings, the total sum amounts to LE 74,931 for new works and 4000 for petty construction and repairs. The Barrage or Delta Prison was completed and occupied during the year and cost L.E. 40,711, but a portion of this sum was met from the grant of 1905.4 sum of L.E. 30,357 was expended on the nev Reformatory, which will be completed during the current year; L.E. 3312 went to Abou Zaabal in enlarging existing accommodation and building a hospital; and a combine hospital and administration block at Tum accounted for L.E. 1388. The balance L.E. 10,701 owing for the Assiout an Keneh prisons was also paid from the grant of the year. This practically completes the large central prisons, and grants in future years will be devoted to the smaller second class prisons. I fear that the estimates for the Reformatory will be considerably exceeded before it is completed and equipped. However the sale of the old site will more than cov such expenditure, as the land, owing to its proximity to the new bridge has increased considerably in value since the proposal to sell the old site, and thus provide the money required for the new building, was approved by the Finance Ministry.
CONCLUSION

Anyone taking the trouble to study the various Tables I have given in the text of this report will learn that, in practically every respect, the year's work shows a record and trust that the Minister will be satisfied with the results achieved. At the same time the is, I fear, a growing feeling amongst the col munity in general and officials in particular that prison life is not now sufficiently dete rent and that the swing of the pendulum h carried the Administration too far in the direction of humanity, if not luxury.

I may at once confess that without extreme severity, if not brutality, it is very difficult to make prison life deterrent to the average fellah, as the ordinary dictates of humanity as recognised in Europe become in Egypt luxuries unless very sparingly applied. Bearing this in mind, I am constantly taking stock of my own regulations and I have lost no opportunity of inviting magistrates and other officials to visit the prisons and freely criticise anything they consider amiss. In this way I have received much assistance, but I think that the general conclusion we have all arrived at is that regulations leave little to be desired, and all that is required is the strict enforcement of discipline.

In the concluding paragraphs of my report last year I dwelt on this question of discipline and I would once more urge on the Directors of prisons that the enforcement of discipline is the crucial test of prison administration. Discipline regulations may be all that one desires, but it is only the Officer in charge of the prison who can see them carried out. The degree of cleanliness we have now reached is remarkable and in the matter of labour the work our prisoners get through will compare favorably with any country, but we have, I fear, still much to learn as regards discipline. I admit that there are many difficulties; communications from outside are frequent where consideration of climate necessitates open cell windows, and extramural labour other than in quarries surrounded by an armed guard, is demoralising for both warders and prisoners and leads to all sorts of abuse. But Egyptian warders will, 1 trust, in time learn that the introduction of tobacco and other articles for prisoners means instant dismissal, if found out, and that familiarity with a prisoner is as grave a breach of discipline as undue severity.

When, however, all is said and done, I. would ask the English Magistrates and Inspectors not to expect too much from prison Directors. It has been truly recorded that "for good or evil, a Police force is a fair index of| the Society in which it is found" and this holds good equally for prison warders. When prisoners, relatives are one and all prepared to pay, whether it be piastres or pounds, for services or supposed services rendered, it is useless to contend that every worker should be immaculate, and like the police man the warder is the bedrock we have eventually to deal with. But if in this respect : no great change can be expected till the general morality of the community from which warders are drawn improves, an ameliora lj tion in the conditions of warder service would undoubtedly have some effect. A warder with several years service counting towards al: pension will certainly not sacrifice his position for the sake of a few piastres, and I look to the establishment of a superannuation fund as a great incentive to honesty. I trust. therefore that a proposal I have made for the creation of such a fund will meet with the approval of the Finance Ministry.
*Sir A. Colvin "Modern Egypt."

div.head: THE 14TH OF JULY
div.p: The French national fête having fallen this year on Sunday the memorial mass at the Capucins church was very largely attended and particularly impressive. The presence of perhaps no less than 200 mariners and officers from H. M. 8. "Queen" and the "Irresistible" lent an additional interest to the mass, and a striking effect of colour to the crowd. From the Church the French Consul General and staff proceeded to the Consulate to a hold a state reception. As usual the Vali of Beyront, and the acting Governor General of the Lebanon, the different Consuls and indeed all the civil and military authorities of both provinces, as well as the clerical dignitaries and a large number of friends and partisans of the French Consulate called to express their congratulations. Admiral Sir Charles Drury, being grand officer of the Legion d'Honneur, and having also regard to the particularly friendly relations between the two nations, cemented by the Entente Cordiale, called also with some of his staff accompanied by the British Vice-Consul, Mr. Rawlins, and on the next day Mr. Albert Fouques Dupare returned the compliment on board the flagship. About the close of the reception Mr. George Covillon, as deputé de la Nation, made a patriotic speech in which he reviewed the chief events of the year that were calculated to shape the history of the fatherland, both in relation to its internal and external relations with the world at large, and he made special reference to the grand mission of France in the East and its special work in this part thereof. The Consul General replied with a few well. chosen words. At midday the consul general and staff together with some represen. tative notabilities of the French colony proceeded to the French Club. In the evening the French consulate was illuminated in honour of the commemorative fete.

div.head: Lebanon's Now Governor,
div.p:
Youssef Pasha Franco, the new Governor General of the Lebanon, left Constantinople yesterday by the Russian steamer and is due here on Wednesday next. panied with three Lebanese officers, will be meeting his Excellency at Mersine. Obituaries.

Death has reaped this month & rich harvest of notabilities. Besides the demise of the late Governor General of the Lebanon there has to be chronicled in this month's obituary that of the wife of the Vali of Beyrouth, which was telegraphed from Constantinople, and of the popular millionaire Ibrahim Sursock, who was allied through his daughters and one of his sons, to prominent members of the Syrian families, such as the Tabets, the Karams, and the Trads. The late Ibrahim Sursock had | been suffering from a chronic illness for several years past, and he finally succumbed on Wednesday at his residence at Souk El Gharb, whence his mortal remains were transported in a solemn procession to Beyront, to be interred in the family vault at St Dimitri's Cemetery. The imposing funeral was such as befitted the deceased's high social rank, and the Orthodox Bishop, Monsignor Messara, between whom and the deceased there existed mutual affection and esteem, delivered after the church service a funeral address wherein he expressed with pathetic and simple eloquence his personal feelings of sorrow, and recounted the qualities and virtues of the deceased.

The Greek Catholic Community lost also two of its notables. Michel Hoekké an old and respectable merchant of high standing, and President of the Greek Catholic charitable Society, also Selim Zehil, General Agent of the French Steamship Company Cyprian Fabre," | a man of rare honesty in business, and of no common ability Personal,

Madame Muzaffer Pasba left by the Messageries steamer on the 13th instant. By the same steamer left also Mr. Ernest Weakley, commercial attaché of His Britannic Majesty's Embassy at Constantinople. The chief object of Mr. Weakley's visit was to inspect the Beyrout Customs and investigate the alleged abuses that have determined the scheme of reform imposed by the Powers as a condition of acceptance of the 3% increase of duty.

div.head: OUR POLICE
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, -A straw serves to show the way the wind blows, and in the disputes between natives and Europeans incident to every-day life in cosmopolitan cities such as Alexandria and Cairo, the police evince an apathy which goes far to justify the assertion that they are, in slang phraseology, "Sitting on the fence" and could not be relied upon in an emergency. While I am willing to admit that the authorities make the best of the material at command, the native policeman generally lacks promptitude and intelligence in the execution of his duties and, when he does put in an appearance, it is usually | too late to prevent mischief. I am of the opinion that if the force were leavened a with a sprinkling of Sudanese soldiers from the Coast-Guard-Service they would set a salutary example to their Egyptian colleagues. The Coast Guard Administration possesses a very fine body of men and it is e a service calculated to develop resource and st initiative in the individual in a greater measure than we can expect to find these t qualities in the case of time expired sol-1 diers of the Egyptian army, who, lacking the regular drill and perhaps sterner military discipline of the ranks, are apt to depreciate in value amidst the temptations P and allurements of town life. The Sudanese is a convivial gentleman betimes but he has | 8 a stern sense of duty and is, I believe, li less prone to fall a victim to the blandisha ments of backsheesh than his Egyptian bro-|I ther. As recently pointed out by a corres in pondent in your columns, in any emergency b in this country, such as, for example, the st Tabah frontier incident, it would not be the tu Egyptian on which the Government would rely but, in the first instance, the Coast P Guards and then the Sudanese Battalion of a the Egyptian Army.
Truly Yonts,

div.head: LORD CROMER AND ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE,"|

Sir, -The fact that only 29 English-residente & in Alexandria out of a thousand showed sufficient interest in a memorial to Lord Cromer to ir answer Mr. R. J. Moss's circular is not surprising. I see that the foreign newspapers state that this attitude of indifference must be ne attributed to the manner in which Lord Cromer In deliberately sacrificed the interests of the colony to political exigencies. Could there be any more salient case than that of the abolition of the British Court as it existed in the days of Sir Charles Cookson 1 That Court was abolished as a principle court and reduced to the status of a provincial court because its existence supported the capitulation, which were radically obnoxious to Lord Cromer. The result of this policy now is that the judges are at Constantinople and pay now and again visits to Egypt. Yet our commercial interests here are far superior to what they are at Constantinople.

We have hundreds of English Companies here, registered under the Companies Acts, and representing tens of millions of pounds of capital, and yet our permanent consular I judges at Alexandria and Cairo have no | legal qualifications whatsoever. The absurdity of the present system was amply demonstrated in | a recent case, when although all the parties concerned were residents in Egypt and the matter involved real property in Egypt, yet the case had to be heard at Constantinople, and considerable expense had to be incurred to send counsel thither in order to deal with a question of law which was purely Egyptian. This most inconvenient state of things is solely due to Lord Cromer, who, as I said above, sacrificed the interest of the colony for "la haute politique." Steps should be taken to at once remedy this state of things by having one of the Constantinople judges to reside permanently in Egypt.
Truly your,

div.head: WORN OUT BY PAIN.
A Mother's Tribulatione. Aoute Headaches and Nervoushees
Disordered Stomach and Liver. Now Blessed with Good Health.

div.p: "All women will admit that the worry of rearing a family is not accomplished withont| considerable suffering at some time of life, sometimes sooner, sometimes later," said Mrs. Charlton, of 19 Aston Brook-street, Aston, Birmingham. "I had clear proof of that a little time back, when my health gave way to such an extent that I became a misery to my friends and myself, and though I have regained my strength and activity now, I must confess that the whole credit for my cure is due to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.

"Only a few months ago," continued Mrs. Charlton, "I became a martyr to violent THESE WERE HER SYMPTOMS, headaches. A burning pain, encircled my forehead, and by the end of the day I was quite tired ont with the agony; yet when I went to bed the throbbing would not allow me to close my eyes. For hours I would lie awake, longing for rest and sleep. When I got up in the morning my head swam, and I would become so dizzy that I fell back on the bed. My side seemed as though weighted heavily, while my liver was sluggish. Nervousness gained such a hold on me that the least noise sent thrilling pains through my whole body. My eyes grew dell and sunken; there was a nauseous taste in my mouth; my skin became sallow and dry, and my cheeks fell in so much that my altered appearance caused much alarm.

"If I drank & cup of tea I was sure to be afflicted with nausea and vomiting. I had always enjoyed the company of friends, but now I was of such a nervous temperament that I became a recluse. Also I lacked the strength to venture out of doors. The least thing made me terribly agitated; my hands trembled, and became so useless that if I picked up anything it fell from my grasp. I took all sorts of medicines, but only seemed to get worse. A doctor said I was suffering from disordered stomach, biliousness, and liver complaint

"It then occurred to me that many cases of people being 'cured by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills had come under my notice, and I obtained a supply of these pills. At first I could trace | little improvement, but continued them, until after taking a few boxes I felt such relief that I could sleep soundly at night and always wake in the morning refreshed. My household duties became a pleasure, and I regained my former strength and energy. All my pains and the throbbing headaches vanished, and my nerves were calmed and fortified. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills imparted new life to my feeble system, and drove out all poisons." ..

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la démolition de sept maisons sises'aux Abassiri, Balactaria et rue el Ghedawi.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 60(soixante).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau du Secrétariate Technique où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 6 Aout 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour la démolition de diverses maisons (sept)."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 6 Aout 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 24 juillet 1907.
Supplement Commercial et Financier
DE . " L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de 1'Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revner complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les dernière statistiques jusqu'a la veille de sa publication : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies, des dépêches officielles de voyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association, ecete
L'abonnement pour une annén en Egypte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de porto ; popi l'estranger 10 P.T. deport en sus
